etymologies: mid 19th century. From animalcule or its etymon post-classical Latin animalculum + -ism, probably after French animalculisme

definitions: The theory that the embryo exists as a preformed entity in the spermatozoon (as opposed to in the ovum). Compare "animalcule". Opposed to ovism.

notes.text: In early use also: †the theory that animalcules are the cause of infectious disease (obsolete. rare).
